description.narrative: Promote an inclusive political resolution to the conflict in Syria and a more stable and inclusive Iraq through meeting immediate stabilisation needs in both countries.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative: FL §06.32.08.80 Global Framework for Integrated Stabilisation Efforts (development assistance)

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Percentage of locations prioritised for stabilisation have been responded to.
Percentage of locations prioritised for stabilisation have been responded to.

target.value: Prioritised operational tasking in support of UNDP and GoI stabilisation plans. 100% of prioritised tasks will be responded to in liberated areas.

actual.value:
As of 31 March 2018 884 threat Impact assessments has been completed.
UNMAS through its implementing partners has assessed more than 70 million sqm and cleared 3.59 million sqm of suspected and contaminated land.
In doing so. UNMAS Iraq has removed 1413 IED and 49946 ERW.
UNMAS has supported 56 assessment missions to liberated areas.
UNMAS has supported 701 UNDP stabilisation tasks. and thereby responded to 100% of the received request.

target.value: Funds disbursed late December 2016 and early January 2017.
Prioritised operational tasking in support of UNDP and GoI stabilisation plans including emergency response to the Mosul Operation 100% of prioritised tasks will be responded to.

actual.value:
UNMAS removed 421 IEDs. 1781 IED component parts and 3676 ERW. Leading to 123 liberated areas becoming accessible for stabilisation and humanitarian efforts.
Between 1 April and 31 September 2017 488 threat impact assessments has been completed across the liberated areas and 530 assessments are ongoing. UNMAS has responded to all tasking received from UNDP FFS and are also conducting assessments to pave the way for the humanitarian response.
UNMAS and its implementing partners has assessed more than 9 million sqm and cleared 608.790 sqm of suspected and contaminated hazardous land.

target.value: # of locations prioritised for stabilisation that have been responded to.

actual.value: With 100% (1483 locations) of prioritised requests from UNDP and government, stabilisation activities responded to with explosive hazard management interventions, UNMAS effectively made communities safer and prevented numerous deaths and injuries.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: A nationally led response to threat of explosive hazards operates efficiently and effectively.

Description: United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS) addresses a critical precondition for effective stabilisation and the return of IDPs in the form of removal of large amounts of unexploded ordnance left behind by retreating ISIL forces in liberated areas in Iraq.

target.value: Square meter cleared of explosive hazards.

title.narrative: Development of national risk education strategy.
Development of national risk education strategy.

target.value: Operational risk education capacity for retaken areas in place. particularly in view of the pressure on IDPs to return home to strategic locations such as Mosul. Hawija. Fallujah. Ramadi. Baiji. and Tel Afar.

actual.value: By 31 March 2018. 517.780 Iraqis had received MRE (67.486 women. 70.214 men. 182.127 girls and 196.775 boys). In addition. two trainings on mine risk education management were provided to 11 IKMAA. 5 DMA in addition to 17 NGO staff. Moreover 188 humanitarian personnel and 1.260 UNDP ‘cash for work’ employees received relevant risk education awareness training.

target.value: Operational risk education capacity in retaken areas in place particularly in view of IDPs fleeing Mosul.

actual.value: MRE were provided to 179.949 beneficiaries (24.888 women. 29.371 men. 59.958 girls and 65.732 boys).

target.value: Funds disbursed late December 2016 and early January 2017.
Development of national risk education strategy.

actual.value: Nationally led strategic coordination mechanisms were strengthened in support of a common approach to clearance of EH through inclusive coordination meeting co-chaired by UNMAS and the DMA

title.narrative: Development of national IED threat mitigation framework and SOP’s.
Development of national IED threat mitigation framework and SOP’s.

target.value: Technical documentation for the clearance of IEDs in contaminated areas updated and in use.

actual.value: GoI has prepared a National Mine Action Strategy with support from UNMAS and are now in the stages of designing a printed version and organising a launch ceremony.

target.value: IED-Disposal Standard Operating Procedures are drafted in conjunction with the National Authority.

actual.value: IED Disposal SOPs were drafted, in conjuction with the Directorate of Mine Action, and submitted for their review and integration into national procedures. UNMAS also supported the drafting of the National Strategy on Mine Action, and Iraq's deadline extension request under its Mine Ban Treaty obligations.

target.value: Funds disbursed late December 2016 and early January 2017.

IED-Disposal Standard Operating Procedures are drafted in conjunction with the National Authority.
Nationally-led strategic coordination mechanisms are strengthened to support a common approach to clearance of explosive hazards through inclusive coordination meetings co-chaired by UNMAS.

actual.value:
The work with DMA on developing national IED-Disposal SOP’s are ongoing.
UNMAS meets frequently with DMA and ISF in both Baghdad and the field. It seems DMA has been better empowered from GoI. and consequently. is better positioned to coordinate what should be an Iraqi-led effort.
